question.text: The assimilatory power formed in light reaction of photosynthesis is:

options.text: <math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>

solution.text: The light reaction of photosynthesis involves the use of direct sunlight and takes place inside the grana of the chloroplast. In the series of this reaction ATP and <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> are generated and are called the assimilatory power. Photolysis of water takes place during this reaction with the evolution of oxygen. They are so-called because during the dark reaction of photosynthesis they are used to provide the energy required for <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> assimilation.
